II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

1. 

Socioeconomic Context 

Cambodia’s power sector was severely damaged during long periods of conflict and civil 
3. 
war.  Private,  independent  power  producers4
  using  their  own  generation  from  imported  diesel 
and  heavy  fuel  oil  were  engaged  in  1994  to  provide  electricity  to  main  load  centers  such  as 
Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, Sihanoukville, and other provincial towns through isolated systems. 
Since 2005, a primary focus of power development has been to build high-voltage (230 kV and 
115 kV) and medium-voltage (22 kV) sub-transmission lines to import electricity from neighbor 
countries  and  provide  affordable  services,  build  demand,  and  facilitate  grid  extension  by 
connecting  the  isolated  systems.  By  2012,  four  high-voltage  lines  were  in  operation,  three  at 
115 kV (414.95 km) and one at 230 kV (91 km). Development of three distinct grid systems is 
progressing in the southern, eastern, and northeastern economic zones. 

4. 
At about 26%, the rate of household electrification in Cambodia is among the lowest in 
Southeast Asia—80% of Cambodia's population lives outside provincial and district towns, and 
only 11% of households in these areas are connected to grid electricity supply, mainly through 
isolated  systems  owned  and  operated  by  private  rural  electricity  enterprises  (REEs)  that 
generate their own power from imported diesel and heavy fuel oil. More than 11 million people 
use rechargeable car batteries for electricity supply, and kerosene and candles for lighting. 

5. 
Electricity from rechargeable car batteries and REEs is expensive. In areas supplied by 
REEs, electricity tariffs are highly volatile due to fluctuating fuel prices and range from $0.65 per 
kilowatt-hour  (kWh)  to  $0.90/kWh.  For  electricity  from  rechargeable  car  batteries,  the  cost 
averages $1.00/kWh. 

Besides being expensive, electricity services from REE-operated systems are generally 
6. 
unreliable and of poor quality. Coupled with high electricity costs, this severely constrains quality 
of  life.  Domestic  firms  and  foreign  investors  name  the  high  costs  and  supply  shortages  of 
electricity as a main constraint to doing business in Cambodia. This is critical, especially as the

2. 

Institutional Arrangements 

7. 
The  key  organizations  in  Cambodia’s  power  sector  are  the  General  Department  of 
Energy under the Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy; the Electricity Authority of Cambodia 
(EAC); EDC; REEs; and other private domestic and foreign investors. 

8. 
The  General  Department  of  Energy  guides  and  supervises  the  development  of  the 
power  sector  and  is  responsible  for  overall  energy  planning,  policy,  and  strategy.  EAC  is  the 
country’s  regulatory  agency,  responsible  for  issuing  rules,  regulations,  and  procedures  and 
governing  the  power  market  operators,  both  suppliers  and  users.  EDC,  the  country’s  national 
power  utility,  is  responsible  for  electricity  production,  transmission,  and  distribution  in  licensed 
areas assigned to EDC by EAC. 

9. 
To  supplement  the  capability  of  EDC  in  developing  power  sector  infrastructure,  the 
government is encouraging the private sector to invest. The promotion of private participation in 
electrification  is  also  anchored  in  Cambodia’s  Electricity  Law  (2001).  REEs  represent  an 
important  private  sector-based  framework  for  developing,  operating,  and  maintaining  the 
country’s  distribution  network.5
  In  addition,  private  domestic  and  foreign  investors  are 
encouraged  to  invest  in  (i)  oil  and  gas  exploitation,  (ii)  energy  generation  from  indigenous 
resources such as hydropower, and (iii) developing the high-voltage transmission system. 

3. 

Subsector Problems and Constraints 

10. 
Technical  sustainability.  Cambodia’s  high  electricity  tariffs  are  caused  by  its  power 
infrastructure, which is still dominated by isolated, inefficient generation and distribution systems 
powered  by  diesel  and  heavy  fuel  oil.  With  the  realization  of  large-scale  domestic  power 
generation,  the  electricity  grid  will  continue  to  evolve.  It  is  planned  that  by  2015,  large-scale 
power generation, mainly from hydropower, will reach 1,116 megawatts, all of which is to meet 
domestic demand estimated to grow at an average 26% per annum up to 2015. An additional 
1,489 km of 230 kV and 115 kV transmission lines are expected to be operational by 2015. 

11. 
The expansion of power generation and the high-voltage transmission network requires 
that medium-voltage sub-transmission and low-voltage (<0.4 kV) distribution lines be developed 
commensurately  to  transfer  electricity  to  consumers.  It  is  estimated  that  about  17,000  km  of 
medium-voltage  sub-transmission  lines  need  to  be  built  to  connect  the  isolated  systems 
throughout  the  country.  These  developments  will  help  displace  expensive,  unreliable,  and 
environmentally  and  health-wise  hazardous  off-grid  diesel  generation  by  REEs  and  will  partly 
contribute to reducing electricity costs. EAC is implementing a tariff policy that requires REEs to 
gradually  reduce  retail  tariffs  to  at  least  $0.28/kWh  within  2–3  years  of  being  connected  to 
EDC’s 22 kV sub-transmission backbone.6
 

Financial  capacity.  EDC  does  not  receive  budgetary  support.  It  needs  to  mobilize 
12. 
external financing to build the country’s grid-electricity infrastructure. While independent power 
producers are investing in power generation and construction of high-voltage transmission lines, 
EDC is primarily responsible for investing in the extension of medium-voltage sub-transmission 

                                                
5  Most REEs operate under a consolidated generation and distribution license. Most of the roughly 300 licensees In 

2012 are consolidated licensees. 

6  Through the connection to EDC’s 22 kV sub-transmission backbone, REEs will receive lower-cost electricity at a 
regulated bulk-supply tariff of $0.13–$0.15 per kWh. The tariff is discounted depending on the distance of the REE 
from EDC’s network. The cost savings are gradually transferred to end-consumers in public consultation with the 
serviced community. Although affordability to pay for electricity consumption must be considered, the tariff strategy 
aims to encourage REEs to further expand their distribution network into lower-density, higher-cost areas. 

 3 

lines.  The  cost  of  doing  so  beyond  provincial  towns,  estimated  at  $21,000  per  km,  is  high. 
Coupled with low population density and low consumption, the return on investment is marginal 
and  will,  without  concessionary  financing  from  development  partners,  imperil  EDC’s  long-term 
financial sustainability. 

13. 
Affordability.  Affordability  represents  a  major  barrier  to  increasing  grid-electricity 
supply. On an average monthly income of $98, a household will need to pay $70–$120 to get 
connected to the grid (including connection fee, wiring from the meter, and house wiring). The 
government  is  trying  to  relieve  the  situation  by  piloting  a  scheme  that  provides  lower-income 
households with interest-free loans to finance connection to the grid. The pilot is implemented 
by the Department of Rural Electrification Fund, a department established under EDC in August 
2012.  The  operational  capacity  of  the  department  needs  to  be  strengthened  to  scale  up  the 
interest-free loan scheme. 

Human  resource  development.  To  allow  EDC  to  efficiently  and  effectively  keep  pace 
14. 
with  the  expansion  requirements,  human  resource  capacity  in  the  key  business  areas  of 
strategic, operational, financial, information technology, and human resource management need 
to  be  strengthened,  and  pertinent  strategies,  policies,  processes,  and  procedures  need  to  be 
further updated, developed, and implemented. 

4. 

Strategy and Road Map 

In  its  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  (NSDP),  2009–2013,  the  government 
15. 
recognizes the importance of developing the energy sector to ensure socioeconomic growth and 
thereby  reduce  poverty  to  at  least  19.5%  by  2015.  The  government  has  developed  the  2011 
Strategy  and  Plan  for  Development  of  Rural  Electrification  in  the  Kingdom  of  Cambodia 
(SPDRE)  to  achieve  52%  household  electrification  by  2020  and  70%  household  electrification 
by  2030,  mainly  by  expanding  the  country’s  grid-electricity  infrastructure.  EDC  is  primarily 
responsible for investing in the expansion of the 22 kV sub-transmission backbone network to 
connect the grid substations of provincial towns to existing and new distribution networks owned 
and  operated  by  REEs.  REEs  will  continue  to  play  an  important  role  in  providing  electricity  to 
consumers after connection to EDC’s sub-transmission grid. 

5. 

Asian Development Bank Sector Experience 

The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  greatly  contributed  to  the  expansion  of 
16. 
electricity access, sector reforms, and institutional capacity building by continuously supporting 
the power sector with investments and technical assistance.7 ADB’s country assistance program 
evaluation  for  Cambodia,  1998–2008  assessed  the  energy  sector  assistance  strategy  and 
program as relevant, effective, likely sustainable, and substantial in impact.8
 

17. 
The  country  assistance  program  evaluation  identified  efficiency  issues  related  to 
implementation  delays.  Delays  can  partly  be  attributed  to  EDC’s  limited  human  resource  and 
operating  capacity  for  (i)  finalizing  detailed  technical  designs,  (ii)  handling  procurement,  and 
(iii) implementing  safeguard  measures  in  an  effective  and  timely  manner.  The  risk  of 
implementation delays under this project will be mitigated by (i) a high degree of readiness for 
subproject 
land  clearance  and  other 
government approvals, as well as advanced procurement in place before the proposed loan is

6. 

Rationale for the Sector Loan Modality 

A sector loan provides consistent and coordinated support to EDC with a critical amount 
18. 
of  financing  for  physical  and  nonphysical  investments  in  line  with  the  objectives  of  the  NSDP 
and SPDRE. Those objectives are fully consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy and 
its energy assessment strategy and road map for 2011–2013.9 Three of five subprojects to be 
financed  as  part  of  the  sector  loan  have  been  appraised  and  approved  with  regard  to  their 
technical,  financial,  economic  viability,  and  environmental  and  social  sustainability.  Two  more 
subprojects, already determined, will be appraised and approved during the implementation of 
the project. The sector loan approach internalizes the appraisal and approval of these additional 
subprojects in accordance with technical, financial, economic, environmental, and social criteria 
mutually  agreed  upon  between  ADB  and  EDC.10
 With the  existence  of  a road map,  subsector 
strategy, and institutional development framework strongly owned by the government and EDC, 
the key requirements for using the sector loan modality are met. 

7. 

Development Partner Coordination 

19. 
Development  partner  coordination  has  in  the  past  provided  the  government  with 
opportunities to synergize interventions from ADB, the World Bank, and bilateral partners, and 
to capitalize on best practices. Physical investment requirements of an estimated $1.0 billion are 
required  to  achieve  the  government’s  electrification  objectives,  exceeding  the  financing 
available from any one development partner. By providing financial support for improving both 
physical  infrastructure  and  institutional  development,  ADB  will  continue  to  add  value  to 
Cambodia’s  energy  sector.  Moreover,  through  effective  development  coordination,  ADB  could 
leverage additional financing for this project from OFID. 

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

20. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  increasing  access  to  grid  electricity  in  Cambodia.  The 
outcome  of  the  project  is  expanded  supply  of  reliable  and  cost-effective  grid  electricity  in 
Kampong Thom, Kampong Cham, Siem Reap, Kandal and Banteay Meanchey provinces. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

1. 

Component 1: Expanding Medium-Voltage Sub-Transmission Network 

21. 
Component 1 of the project will support EDC in the expansion of 22 kV sub-transmission 
lines. These sub-transmission lines will be connected from grid substations in provincial towns to 
existing  and  new  distribution  and  service  lines  owned  and  operated  by  REEs.  The  project  will 
finance  the  construction  of  2,110  km  of  sub-transmission  lines  divided  into  five  provincial 
subprojects: (i) 625 km in Kampong Thom, (ii) 184 km in Kampong Cham, (iii) 866 km in Siem 
Reap,  (iv)  263  km  in  Kandal,  and  (v)  173  km  in  Banteay  Meanchey  province.  Subproject  1  in 
Kampong Thom, subproject 2 in Kampong Cham, and subproject 3 in Siem Reap province have 
been fully appraised and approved.

2. 

Component 2: Supporting EDC in Implementing Subprojects 

22. 
Component 2 will support EDC in implementing the subprojects with a focus on finalizing 
detailed engineering design, procurement and contract management, construction supervision, 
testing  and  commissioning,  implementation  and  monitoring  of  social  and  environmental 
safeguards, project performance monitoring and evaluation. Project implementation consultants 
will complement existing staff of EDC, thus ensuring a high degree of implementation efficiency 
of subprojects financed under the project. On-the-job training to EDC staff in procurement and in 
the preparation and implementation of safeguard documents and gender-balanced compliance 
measures will be provided. 

3. 

Component  3:  Improving  the  Operational  Effectiveness  and  Efficiency  of 
EDC 

Component  3  will  support  EDC  in  developing  and  implementing  strategies,  policies, 
23. 
processes, and procedures to effectively and efficiently manage its growing operations. Courses 
will be provided to EDC management and staff to strengthen the institutional capacity in various 
key  operational  areas  including  (i)  strategic  corporate  planning  and  management,  (ii)  financial 
management and investment planning, and (iii) gender-balanced human resource management. 
This component will support the operational integration of the recently established Department 
of Rural Electrification Fund and will also include the rollout of EDC’s financial accounting and 
enterprise public utility organization management information system to its provincial branches.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The  22  kV  sub-transmission  line  routes  are  generally  designed  along  major  roads.15
30. 
 
Three-phase lines have been favored, as the lines will form the backbone of the grid-electricity 
network and can be subsequently overlaid with appropriate two-wire, single-phase spur lines for 
villages away from the major roads. The required transformer capacity, medium-voltage feeder 
route  and  rating  have  been  sized  on  peak  household  demand  assuming  a  standard  load  of 
0.375  kilovolt-ampere  per  household  and  considering  that,  within  5  years,  at  least  80%  of 
households  will  be  connected  to  the  grid.  The  grid  substations  in  Kampong  Cham,  Kampong 
Thom,  and  Siem  Reap  are  currently  supplied  with  imports  from  Viet  Nam  and  Thailand.  The 
power  purchase  is  sufficient  to  service  additional  connections.  The  supply  capacity  from  grid 
substations in provincial towns and the voltage performance were reviewed in a power system 
analysis. The project includes the installation of automatic voltage regulators to maintain voltage 
performance of long medium-voltage feeders. The design for subprojects 1, 2, and 3 is found to 
be technically viable.

of 12% and weighted average cost of capital of 1.6%, respectively. The economic and financial

D. 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

35. 
A  household  survey  conducted  in  the  project  areas  suggests  that  the  primary  use  of 
commercial electricity supplies is to partially replace the use of kerosene for lighting and of car 
batteries  for  other  electrical  appliances.  With  the  development  of  the  22  kV  sub-transmission 
line  network,  the  average  electricity  cost  for  consumers  will  be  gradually  reduced  by  at  least 
60%,  allowing  households  to  increase  consumption.  Non-household  consumers  such  as  rice 
mills,  craft  work,  and  small  service  businesses  are  present  in  the  project  areas  and  economic 
activities are likely to increase with more cost-effective and reliable electricity supply. 

36. 
The Department of Rural Electrification Fund is already implementing a pilot scheme of 
providing  lower-income  households  with  interest-free  loans  to  finance  the  connection  to  the 
electricity grid. Component 2 of the project supports EDC with the operational integration of the 
Department  of  Rural  Electrification  Fund,  which  will  involve  the  development  of  strategies, 
policies, processes, and procedures for scaling up the provision of interest-free loans to at least 
10,000 per year. The government and EDC have given their assurances to continue efforts to 
increase connectivity of households and lower electricity costs to consumers so as to maximize 
the socioeconomic benefits of the project. Support mechanisms are to be provided to all eligible 
households  irrespective  of  ethnicity,  gender  of  household  head,  or  other  conditions  of 
vulnerability. 

37.  Women occupy key roles in EDC in management, procurement, administration, finance 
and accounting, and corporate and business planning. The project supports the implementation 
of  a  human  resource  policy  encouraging  gender  balance  at  all  levels  as  well  as  capacity 
development  of  female  staff  in  the  various  departments.  In  addition,  the  project  ensures  that 
100%  of  affected  households  headed  by  women  are  consulted  on  resettlement  plans;  joint 
certification of male and female household members is required on compensation receipts; and
